history.content:
Based on the number of semesters attended, so sophomore.

Employers care more about which and how many courses you've taken than you're actual year - so junior is fine.
Employers will more likely than not ask for you intended graduation date. This is a number that you can say whatever you feel comfortable saying.

Based on the number of semesters attended, so sophomore.


Employers care more about which and how many courses you've taken than you're actual year - so junior is fine.
Based on the number of semesters attended, so sophomore.

children.subject: I disagree with this. If you're planning on graduating in three years and you're on track to do so with courses you can say you're a junior. It's not disingenuous as this individual would be on par with their respective junior level classmates.

I am a bit skeptical of the claim that a second-year who is graduating in three years is necessarily on par with a third-year who is graduating with four. I wouldn't expect that the number of technical classes that the former has taken to be significantly more than that of a second-year who is graduating in four.

I mean this is up to the discretion of the individual after all. The number of technical courses is not nearly as important as the courses one takes, ie some individuals take 170/189/126 in their sophomore year first semester and get A's whereas these are all advanced courses that would be spread out for another individual.

There is a well-agreed-upon definition of what constitutes a freshman vs soph vs junior vs senior, namely, the number of years one has been in attendance at the school in question. You can't choose to redefine yourself based on specious, arbitrary criteria like "being on par" with your upperclassmates or doing well in a particular series of classes during a particular semester - the definitions are pretty clear and simple. A highly advanced sophomore is still a sophomore, and a junior who is graduating is still a junior.

You are a sophomore. It is disingenuous to suggest to employers that you might be graduating the following year by saying you're a junior when you aren't. Even if you are planning on graduating after three years, it still doesn't make you a junior, but you should mention that to employers directly if you are looking to be considered for a full time position immediately after your sophomore year.
I just say ____-year (i.e. second year) and give my intended graduation date. It really avoids any and all confusion in my opinion

history.content: This is my opinion, but I agree that ___ year is probably what they are actually asking. You can put on your resume which classes you've taken. I'm not sure that the number of units/class-standing means much without knowing which classes you've taken.
My academic status on CalCentral is junior, but I'm actually a sophomore (I know it's based on my units). When I apply for internship, should I write junior or sophomore as my year? Thanks!
history.subject: actual year or level on CalCentral
